text: After the death of Prophet Muhammad, the Muslim community entered a new phase regarding leadership. This period is called "The Rightly Guided Caliphs." Lasting approximately thirty years, this period was a transitional era when Islamic society took shape both politically and socially. Throughout these years, the primary goal was to maintain social order, ensure justice, and make the newly established social model sustainable.

The caliphate of Abu Bakr began at a time when the need to keep the Muslim community united was at its highest. The most distinctive feature of this period was maintaining social stability despite difficult conditions.

Abu Bakr saw the possibility of division with the emergence of different views as soon as he took office. Therefore, his priority was to keep the community together. He upheld the principle of unity by standing against the attempts of different tribes to separate.

content.section: b) First Steps of Institutional Structure
text: The basic functioning of the new state gained a structural framework with the initiatives during his period. Practical solutions were produced to organize public affairs and respond quickly to the needs of society.

Realizing that the Quranic verses needed to be safely preserved, Abu Bakr took the first step to collect the revelations. This work formed the basis for the reproduction of the Mushaf in later periods.

The era of Umar stands out as a period when justice and administrative order were significantly strengthened. Throughout his ten-year caliphate, he introduced innovations that placed social functioning on solid foundations.

Umar adopted an approach that emphasized administrators being close to the people and accountable. He made permanent regulations in matters such as courts, public order, the tax system, and military structure. These regulations became examples for many governance models in the Islamic world in later years.

He established a systematic mutual aid system for the protection of orphans, the elderly, and the homeless. This approach, which ensured that public resources reached all segments of society, is considered one of the first examples of Islamic social policy.
The creation of new settlement areas, the shaping of the security organization, and the regular meeting of public needs are among the important developments of his period.
The most important work of Uthman's era was the compilation of the Quran into a single Mushaf and its distribution throughout the Islamic geography.

The reproduction of the Mushaf to preserve the Quran from a single source in different regions was an extremely critical step in Islamic history. This work prepared the ground for the book to reach the present day in the same way.

content.section: b) Search for Stability in Governance
text: During Uthman's era, the Islamic geography expanded, and city administrations became more complex. Although there were some discussions about governance during this process, the basic structure of society continued to be preserved.
It was a natural process for different views to emerge as the society grew in this period. The disagreements experienced formed the basis of greater political problems in later periods.
The era of Ali was the period when internal conflicts were most intense in Islamic society. Neutrality in narration is extremely important; therefore, this period is only discussed event-centered.
When Ali took office, society was already in serious tension. His main goal was to re-establish authority and ensure social order.

content.section: b) Internal Conflicts and Political Tensions
text: The internal conflicts that occurred during this period paved the way for political divisions in Islamic society in later years. These events have been the subject of different interpretations throughout history; however, in practice, it is best to convey them in a neutral language, only as historical cases.

content.section: c) Negotiation and Search for Peace
text: Despite all the tensions, Ali made various attempts to stop the bloodshed and re-establish the unity of society.

The era of the Rightly Guided Caliphs was a period when both the foundations of Islamic society were strengthened and it went through important trials. In these years, the understanding of justice, unity, social responsibility, and order came to the fore; at the same time, it was inevitable for society to meet different views. The events of the period deeply affected the subsequent centuries of Islamic history.
Understanding this period is a fundamental step in grasping the developmental stages of Islamic society.
